_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Brakebush-Irving

Irving, TX 75061



Executive Summary



Risk Management Program



Brakebush-Irving, located in Irving, TX, is a production facility offering a range of chicken products.  Brakebush-Irving uses Anhydrous Ammonia as a refrigerant at this facility to provide cooling for the production and storage areas.  Brakebush-Irving is a closed loop system with normal operating pressures that range between a low side of 11.0 in of vacuum to a high side of 185 psi.  The systems maximum intended inventory is 47,410 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.



Worst Case Scenario



Brakebush-Irving worst case release is the catastrophic failure of the High Pressure Receiver in the ammonia system.  The maximum capacity of the High Pressure Receiver is 19,692 lbs. of Anhydrous Ammonia at 100% full.  The normal operating level in the HPR is 40% or 7877 lbs. of Anhydrous Ammonia.  The worst case scenario takes into account the possibility the vessel would be 74% full, holding 14,589 lbs. of Anhydrous Ammonia.  Using the ALOHA program downloaded from the EPA home page, the calculated endpoint was 1.5 miles down wind.  Based on the census data provided the population within the radius of the toxic endpoint is 17,846, with 6,182 residential housing, in the area.  There are no medical center within this area.  



The worst-case scenario is the catastrophic failure of the High Pressure Receiver in the ammonia system.  The vessel capacity of the High Pressure Receiver is described above.  Although the worst case scenario is a requirement by the RMP ruling, it is not a likely scenario to take place.  Brakebush-Irving follows the industrial standards to assure proper material is used in the ammonia refrigeration system.  By following the industrial standards and the EPA/OSHA standards, the shell failure is unlikely.



ANSI/IIAR-2 Standard for Equipment, Design, and Installation of Ammonia Mechanical Refrigeration Systems.



ANSI/ASHRAE 15-1992 Safety Code for Mechanical Refrigeration

ASME/ANSI B31.5 Refrigeration Piping Code



ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code



International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) Bulletin 110 - Start-up, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Mechanical Refrigeration System



International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) Bulletin 116 - Guidelines for: Avoiding Component Failure in Industrial Systems Caused by Abnormal Pressure or Shock



Alternative Release Scenario



The alternative release scenario was determined by using the EPA's RMP Guidance.  The alternative release was a pressure relief valve function or failure was most likely the cause of an ammonia release.  Using the tables provided, a pressure relief valve release 86.76 lbs./min of ammonia for 10 minutes from the High Pressure Receiver.  The toxic endpoint for the release is .1 mile down wind.  The estimated population within the distance would be 240 residents, with 97 residential housing.  There are no schools or hospitals in the area.



Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies:



Brakebush-Irving has established steps to include initial training under the OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.120 HAZWOPER.  The facility has established annual retraining for all personnel that re on the HAZMAT team as well as periodic spill drills and plant wide evacuation drills to assure all employees are prepared in the event of an ammonia release.  Brakebush-Irving has also coordinated efforts with the Fire department to establish a joint response program.  Brakebush-Irving established plans and procedures are periodically reviewed and at least annually assure that they are current and up to date.



Emergency Response Plan:



Brakebush-Irving has trained personnel that are refrigeration operators to assure they can perform their responsibilities and procedures safely.  The refrigeration operators receive training on the ammonia system when there is a change in the system and at minimum of every three years.  Brakebush-Irving has also

trained personnel in the Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response Program, OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120 HAZWOPER.  The trained personnel have been trained at the level of the technicians level responder and also the incident commander on scene.  The trained personnel will assess each release situation and determine by the risk assessment the appropriate emergency response to initiate.  This could be simply tightening a packing nut or a flange bolt or initiating a system shut down.  Brakebush-Irving has established a written operating procedure for the ammonia system and has included in the procedure the emergency shutdown and isolation in the event of a release.  Brakebush-Irving has also purchased the appropriate equipment to support the HAZMAT Team.  The in-house HAZMAT Team will coordinate their efforts with the outside Emergency Services to assure safety for all personnel. 



Five Year Accident History:



There have been no accidental releases in the past five years.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:



OSHA Process Safety Management

EPA Risk Management Program

OSHA HAZWOPER Program

ASME Boiler and Pressure Valve Codes

ANSI B31.3 Piping Code

IIAR Industry Guideline for Safety and Good Engineering Practices

NFPA Guidelines for Fire Protection Equipment



Brakebush-Irving through regular audits, training, maintenance, testing, and inspection programs has established a history of safe operation and that the community emergency action plans are current and in place.  Also, that training with community services has been done and is on going.  This is to ensure that in the event of an accidental release, Brakebush-Irving trained personnel and the community emergency services can minimize the release and stop it with no impact to the employees or the community.
